subject: RE: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
msgSnippet: Its not completely the original design, but what it evolved into. And since we don t have yet a complete suite of tests, we re reluctant to make large-scale
messageBody:
Its not completely the original design, but what it evolved into. And since we don't have yet a complete suite of tests, we're reluctant to make large-scale refactorings  to the code.
Back to the original question (where to put the test classes), I prefer keeping them near the actual code (=the same package). This way these classes are never "outsiders", and you tend to look at them and update them as part of the project itself.



"Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>

11/06/2001 16:08
Please respond to junit

       
        To:        "'junit@yahoogroups.com'" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
        cc:        
        Subject:        RE: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?



IMO...
    > It simply make testing easier, without changing the protection of
existing code.
   > We find it sometimes easy to test part of a flow (which usually
resides in a separate method) rather than
   > check the public interface function.
Then shouldn't these be made part of the public interface and allow the
client to interact with them?  If the client has no business touching these
parts, make them private.
    > Also, I take the term "public interface" as relative. If an object
exposes an interface (set of methods)
   > to its peer objects within its package, I see no reason not to test
it, even though those methods are
   > package-protected.
I guess I disagree here.  I am not convinced that package-potected methods
are part of a public interface.  If they are used that way I would question
whether some refactoring needed to take place.  But that's just my opinion.
I don't want to seem like I am picking on your design decisions.
-Jason
